abstract.text: Gamma ray source detection above 30TeV is an encouraging approach for finding galactic cosmic ray origins.
All sky survey for gamma ray sources using wide field of view detector is essential for population accumulation for various types of sources above 100GeV.
To target the goals, the ARGO-YBJ experiment has been established.
Significant progresses have been made in the experiment.
A large air shower detector array in an area of 1km 2 is proposed to boost the sensitivity.

Hybrid detection with multi-techniques will allow a good discrimination between different types of primary particles, including photons and protons, thus enable an energy spectrum measurement for individual specie.
Fluorescence light detector array will extend the spectrum measurement above 100PeV where the second knee is located.
An energy scale determined by balloon experiments at 10TeV will be propagated to ultra high energy cosmic ray experiments

body_text.text: Introduction
More than 100 sources 1 with emission of gamma rays around 1 TeV have been discovered 2 in the last two decades.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The mechanism of the emission has been investigated somewhat thoroughly among the discovered sources.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Evidences 3 support a scenario in which all kinds of soft photons such as star light or cosmic microwave background (CMB) photons near an object that is associated with a strong shock wave can be converted into TeV gamma rays because they may be knocked by high energy electrons accelerated at the front of the shock waves.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Pulsar wind nebulae (PWN), supernova remnants (SNR), X-ray binaries (Micro-quasars) and active galactic nuclei (AGN) are main categories of gamma ray sources.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Energy spectrum distributions are measured up to nearly 100TeV for some of the sources 4 .
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Most of the observed energy spectra are interpolated quite well using the mechanism based on the inverse Compton scattering model, however, some of them seem to be difficult to fit, thus a more interesting mechanism of gamma ray production based on neutral pion decay is introduced by many authors 5 .
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: It implied that the sources with such a feature may be origins of cosmic rays because pions must be produced in collisions between accelerated protons or nuclei (cosmic ray particles) and ambient material.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: For further investigation, a dedicated detector with very high sensitivity at high energies above 30TeV is required for a clean measurement of gamma ray energy spectrum without any contemplation from cosmic rays.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Due to absorption of extragalactic background light(EBL) or CMB, gamma rays at such high energy can not propagate through the space between galaxies, in other words, the sources must be inside of our galaxy.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: There exist even more complicated phenomena, such as strong transient behaviors of AGNs or gamma ray bursts, etc. the flux of gamma rays could change by orders of magnitudes within a few hours.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: In order to understand what causes such strong and quite frequently flares, collecting sufficient population for different types of sources is necessary.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Lots of interesting physics, such as quantum gravitational effects etc, can be studied through the flare observation.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Narrow field of view (FOV) Cherenkov telescopes for pointing investigation have been very successful in finding most of point sources including highly variable AGNs.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: With an intrinsic difficulty, namely not being able to operate in cloudy weather or with the moon in the sky, the Cherenkov telescopes are not optimized towards monitoring the transient phenomena.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: An all-sky survey for gamma ray sources will be an essential approach.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: A ground based large air shower detector array at high altitude is a natural response to the strong demand.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The ARGO-YBJ experiment is a successful approach along the direction.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: In this paper, the progresses of the experiment are briefly summarized in the next section.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: In order to boost the discovery power of the wide FOV detector in the all sky survey, a much larger detector array is designed as a major upgrade of the current experiment.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: A layout of the new array and corresponding design of detectors are presented in the following sections.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Expected performance of the new array is also reported.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Such a detector array is not only useful for the gamma ray source survey but also plays an important role of bridging between direct measurements of energy spectra of individual cosmic ray species at balloon heights and ultra high energy cosmic ray experiments on the ground, such as Auger and Telescope Array experiments.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Matching with direct measurements that use calorimeters and charge sensitive detectors in 10TeV regime sets an absolute energy scale for air shower experiments on the ground.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The ARGO-YBJ experiment plays an essential role in the measurement of the spectrum in the low energy domain.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: A hybrid of multiple detection techniques plays increasingly important role in the future experiments.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: As a major upgrade, the future experiment at the high altitude of 4300m a.s.l. is designed to cover a wide energy region from 30TeV to few EeV by combining multiple air shower detection techniques together.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The layout of the detector array and corresponding performance are described in the sections before concluding the paper.
body_text.section: Introduction

The ARGO-YBJ Experiment Progresses and Future Extension 3

body_text.text: The ARGO-YBJ Experiment and Its Results
The ARGO-YBJ experiment, located at the YangBaJing Cosmic Ray observatory (Tibet, China, 4300m a.s.l.), is a single layer of Resistive Plate Chambers (RPCs) 6 on a surface of 78 × 74m 2 .
body_text.section: The ARGO-YBJ Experiment and Its Results

body_text.text: The central part has a full coverage area of 5800m 2 with 10×13 clusters which have 12 RPCs in each and each RPC has 10 pads as the basic unit of the detector.
body_text.section: The ARGO-YBJ Experiment and Its Results

body_text.text: The central carpet array is used for event triggering.
body_text.section: The ARGO-YBJ Experiment and Its Results

body_text.text: Outside the carpet, a skirt part of the array, so-called guard ring, made of 23 clusters with a coverage of 25%, is designed to select events that cores of showers are falling inside the array.
body_text.section: The ARGO-YBJ Experiment and Its Results

body_text.text: Cosmic ray data have been collected with a trigger criterion of N hit ≥ 20, where N hit is number of fired pads in a trigger window of 420 ns.
body_text.section: The ARGO-YBJ Experiment and Its Results

body_text.text: The trigger rate for air shower events is ∼3.6kHz.
body_text.section: The ARGO-YBJ Experiment and Its Results

body_text.text: Cosmic ray data from July 2006 to October 2009 are analyzed.
body_text.section: The ARGO-YBJ Experiment and Its Results

body_text.text: The overall exposure is 825.25 days with a duty circle greater than 85% since October 2007.
body_text.section: The ARGO-YBJ Experiment and Its Results

body_text.text: With a measurement of a shadow of galactic cosmic rays blocked by the moon, one learns the angular resolution for the shower arrival direction is better than 0.5 • for showers that N hit > 100.
body_text.section: The ARGO-YBJ Experiment and Its Results

body_text.text: The significance of the shadow is 55σ.
body_text.section: The ARGO-YBJ Experiment and Its Results

body_text.text: This indicates that the ARGO-YBJ detector is running very stable and steadily collecting cosmic ray events.
body_text.section: The ARGO-YBJ Experiment and Its Results

body_text.text: To estimate the sensitivity of the ARGO-YBJ detector in terms of its accumulative exposure, the Crab nebula as a standard candle for γ ray sources in the very high energy region is measured.
body_text.section: The ARGO-YBJ Experiment and Its Results

body_text.text: Photons from the nebula produce an excess of 14.5σ at the maximum over the cosmic ray backgrounds, as shown in Fig.1.
body_text.section: The ARGO-YBJ Experiment and Its Results

body_text.text: With such a sensitivity, many gamma ray astronomic investigations are able to be performed, such as a survey in the whole sky for brightest sources and a monitor for transient effects associated with variable sources, e.g. AGN flares and gamma ray bursts.
body_text.section: The ARGO-YBJ Experiment and Its Results

body_text.text: As examples of a steady source in our galaxy and a blazer that bursts in flares occasionally, our measurement of the newly found MGRO1908+06 7 is shown in the left panel in Fig.2 with a significance of 5.4σ.
body_text.section: The ARGO-YBJ Experiment and Its Results

body_text.text: Mrk421 has many flares in the past years and is also observed by ARGO-YBJ with 11.5σ.
body_text.section: The ARGO-YBJ Experiment and Its Results

body_text.text: Most importantly, the observation of the highly active blazer in a long run demonstrates the power of monitoring for those types of transient phenomena using ARGO-YBJ detector.
body_text.section: The ARGO-YBJ Experiment and Its Results

body_text.text: In the right panel in Fig.2, an accumulation of the excesses in the Mrk421 direction reveals a nice correlation with the hard X-ray (15-50keV) flux measured by the space borne X-ray telescope 8 .
body_text.section: The ARGO-YBJ Experiment and Its Results

body_text.text: A Design of Detector Array for LHAASO
In order to fulfill all the goals mentioned in Sec.1, a large scale complex of many kinds of detectors is needed beyond the ARGO-YBJ experiment.
body_text.section: A Design of Detector Array for LHAASO

body_text.text: For gamma ray source surveys, a water Cherenkov detector array(WCDA) with a total active area of 90,000m 2 is proposed, marked by the four octagons in the left penal in Fig.3
body_text.section: A Design of Detector Array for LHAASO

body_text.text: It is sensitive to gamma ray showers above a few hundred GeV and will achieve a sensitivity of detecting sources that have emission intensity of at least 2% of the  emission from the Crab Nebula I crab with a significance of 5σ per year, as shown in the right penal in Fig.3.
body_text.section: A Design of Detector Array for LHAASO

body_text.text: For discovered sources in the surveys, two types of further investigations can be pursued.
body_text.section: A Design of Detector Array for LHAASO

body_text.text: One is to measure the energy spectra of gamma rays up to few hundreds of TeV for searching for galactic cosmic ray origins.
body_text.section: A Design of Detector Array for LHAASO

body_text.text: The focus is the high energy ends of the spectra where one expects to see differences due to different origins of gamma rays, either from inverse Compton scattering of high energy electrons or from decays of neutral pions which are produced in high energy proton interaction with ambient material near the sources.
body_text.section: A Design of Detector Array for LHAASO

body_text.text: For this purpose, a particle detector array with an effective area of 1km 2 is proposed (KM2A) including a muon detector array with 40,000m 2 active area.
body_text.section: A Design of Detector Array for LHAASO

body_text.text: This allows a clean measurement of gamma ray spectra above 60TeV without any hadronic shower background by selecting muonless showers.
body_text.section: A Design of Detector Array for LHAASO

body_text.text: 5137 scintillator detectors (1m 2 each), shown as the smallest dots in the left penal in Fig.3, are used to measure arrival directions and total energies of showers.
body_text.section: A Design of Detector Array for LHAASO

body_text.text: 1200 µ detectors made of 36 scintillator detectors same as electron detectors but covered by absorber such as 2.5m dirt or 5m water, shown as squares in the left penal in Fig.3, are used for muon content measurements.
body_text.section: A Design of Detector Array for LHAASO

body_text.text: An expected sensitivity of this array is also plotted in the right penal in Fig.3 connecting with the WCDA sensitivity at 10TeV.
body_text.section: A Design of Detector Array for LHAASO

body_text.text: It makes a perfect complementary to the narrow field view CTA experiment which is the most sensitive detector at lower energies and details a morphologic probe within a FOV of 3 • around the sources in the next 5 years.
body_text.section: A Design of Detector Array for LHAASO

body_text.text: The other is to carry out similar morphologic probes at much lower energies, e.g. 30GeV as a further extension of the project.
body_text.section: A Design of Detector Array for LHAASO

body_text.text: It requires adding two MAGIC-II type large size telescopes (LST), similar to that will be used in the central part of CTA, to the LHAASO project at an altitude of 4300m a.s.l., as marked by solid dots in the penal in Fig.3.
body_text.section: A Design of Detector Array for LHAASO

body_text.text: To measure cosmic ray spectra with individual composition, a multi-parameter investigation is necessary.
body_text.section: A Design of Detector Array for LHAASO

body_text.text: In general, the shower maximum, the muon content and the high energy component near the core are three independent parameters that can be used for deducing signatures of different showers induced by different nuclei.
body_text.section: A Design of Detector Array for LHAASO

body_text.text: Two more detector components are proposed for measuring those parameters except for the muon content.
body_text.section: A Design of Detector Array for LHAASO

body_text.text: They are the 24 wide FOV Cherenkov telescope array (WFCA) and the high threshold core-detector array (SCDA) with an effective area of 5000m 2 , shown as three rectangles and a very dense area at the center of the array in the left penal in Fig.3, respectively.
body_text.section: A Design of Detector Array for LHAASO

body_text.text: Physics Perspectives of the LHAASO Project
Investigation for cosmic ray origins among galactic gamma ray sources
RXJ1713-3946, one of the brightest gamma ray sources in the southern sky, has been thoroughly investigated 5 in terms of spectrum measurements and very detailed morphologic probing.
body_text.section: Investigation for cosmic ray origins among galactic gamma ray sources

body_text.text: As a shell type SNR, it has been naturally considered as a candidate of a cosmic ray source, moreover it is difficult to be interpolated as a source with a pure electron origin model according to its gamma ray spectrum.
body_text.section: Investigation for cosmic ray origins among galactic gamma ray sources

body_text.text: However, it has yet been so certain that this SNR is a source of cosmic ray protons.
body_text.section: Investigation for cosmic ray origins among galactic gamma ray sources

body_text.text: A concrete evidence for existence of accelerated protons relies on an accurate measurement of the spectrum extended to higher energies and even more important a collection of many similar sources in our galaxy that have the same feature.
body_text.section: Investigation for cosmic ray origins among galactic gamma ray sources

body_text.text: Using LHAASO KM2A, one will carry out a background-free measurement of spectra for such sources above 60TeV.
body_text.section: Investigation for cosmic ray origins among galactic gamma ray sources

body_text.text: All spectra of discovered sources by HESS are well above the LHAASO sensitivity below few hundred TeV if those sources appear in the northern sky.
body_text.section: Investigation for cosmic ray origins among galactic gamma ray sources

body_text.text: More than 30 events above highest energies ever measured are expected for most of the sources in 3 years.
body_text.section: Investigation for cosmic ray origins among galactic gamma ray sources

body_text.text: According to recent theoretical investigation 9 , old SNRs have greater chances to have a capability of accelerating protons to high energies, thus to produce higher energy photons than the inverse-Compton scattering of electrons.
body_text.section: Investigation for cosmic ray origins among galactic gamma ray sources

body_text.text: All the physics goals set a minimum of requirements on the LHAASO KM2A performance, such as an angular resolution of the array better than 0.5 • and an energy resolution of the array better than 20%, which are all tested successfully in the existing experiments at the Tibet site.
body_text.section: Investigation for cosmic ray origins among galactic gamma ray sources

body_text.text: Full-sky survey for the collection of a gamma ray source population
The number of sources with TeV gamma ray emission has been exponentially increasing since the discovery of the first source, the Crab Nebula, using a narrow FOV Cherenkov telescope in 1989.
body_text.section: Full-sky survey for the collection of a gamma ray source population

body_text.text: Without a guide from surveying results, an efficiency of the discovery of TeV gamma sources remains at 10% among very carefully selected candidates.
body_text.section: Full-sky survey for the collection of a gamma ray source population

body_text.text: After a strong progress in the last twenty years, the rate seems to start slowing down.
body_text.section: Full-sky survey for the collection of a gamma ray source population

body_text.text: According to experience in optical and X-ray astronomy, if there is no boost in sensitivity of the observational survey, the population of sources will not be expected increasing with the same pace.
body_text.section: Full-sky survey for the collection of a gamma ray source population

body_text.text: A demand in the community to have the observational survey with equal sensitivity as the narrow FOV observation, becomes stronger recently.
body_text.section: Full-sky survey for the collection of a gamma ray source population

body_text.text: Ground based shower detector arrays, such as the Milagro experiment, start to demonstrate their power of discovery of sources, especially to sources with spatial extension which is particularly difficult to be observed by the narrow FOV observation.
body_text.section: Full-sky survey for the collection of a gamma ray source population

body_text.text: Following Milagros recent results 10 of confirming some sources found by the space borne FERMI/LAT detector, the ARGO-YBJ experiment confirmed as well that adding all sources in a category together, such as all brightest pulsar TeV sources, excesses are observed given a statistics collected in an operation for slightly longer than 2 years.
body_text.section: Full-sky survey for the collection of a gamma ray source population

body_text.text: The LHAASO project will have a sensitivity of seeing all sources in the whole northern sky that are stronger than 0.02I crab simultaneously.
body_text.section: Full-sky survey for the collection of a gamma ray source population

body_text.text: With a similar sensitivity, HESS has surveyed a very small region near the center of our galaxy that resulted in discoveries of numerous sources.
body_text.section: Full-sky survey for the collection of a gamma ray source population

body_text.text: At least 99% of the sky is yet to be surveyed.
body_text.section: Full-sky survey for the collection of a gamma ray source population

body_text.text: With an operation of LHAASO for 1∼2 years, one half of the sky will be surveyed just like the central region of our galaxy.
body_text.section: Full-sky survey for the collection of a gamma ray source population

body_text.text: "Knees" of individual species and an absolute energy scale

A detector array like LHAASO at a height of 4300m a.s.l. must be used for cosmic ray research because showers around the "knee" just reach their maximum at 1∼2km above the array, thus effects due to shower fluctuations are minimized.
body_text.section: "Knees" of individual species and an absolute energy scale

body_text.text: Since the "knee" was found, its origin has yet to be clarified.
body_text.section: "Knees" of individual species and an absolute energy scale

body_text.text: A major difficulty is how to separate different primary species from each others in shower observations.
body_text.section: "Knees" of individual species and an absolute energy scale

body_text.text: Accurately measuring muon contents in showers with a large enough active detector array is one of the handles.
body_text.section: "Knees" of individual species and an absolute energy scale

body_text.text: LHAASO array, equipped with the largest muon detector array ever, should make its contribution to this topic.
body_text.section: "Knees" of individual species and an absolute energy scale

body_text.text: However, many historic experiments, such as CASA/MIA and Kascade, demonstrated that it is not sufficient to effectively separate species by using the muon content only.
body_text.section: "Knees" of individual species and an absolute energy scale

body_text.text: With a small portion of extension by adding WFCA and SCDA to the project, shower maximum depths, X max and high energy fluxes carried by particles near the shower cores can be measured.
body_text.section: "Knees" of individual species and an absolute energy scale

body_text.text: Simulation shows that the X max can be determined with a resolution of 50g/cm 2 which can be useful for the separation, while a difference of 150g/cm 2 between protons and irons in average is expected in this energy range.
body_text.section: "Knees" of individual species and an absolute energy scale

body_text.text: Simulation also shows that SCDA will help to separate proton showers from others with high purity and efficiency.
body_text.section: "Knees" of individual species and an absolute energy scale

body_text.text: Working together, the three independent pieces of information will greatly enhance the selecting power for protons, helium and iron nuclei on an event by event bases above 30TeV.
body_text.section: "Knees" of individual species and an absolute energy scale

body_text.text: This is particularly important because the spectra of those particles had been measured directly in numerous balloon borne experiments that set an absolute energy scale for the air shower observation.
body_text.section: "Knees" of individual species and an absolute energy scale

body_text.text: Using an array of 5000m 2 , the spectra will be extended up to 10PeV or even higher within two or three years.
body_text.section: "Knees" of individual species and an absolute energy scale

body_text.text: Extension to UHE for the second "knee"

To extend the spectrum to higher energies and make a connection with experiments, such as TA and Auger, at altitudes around 1600m a.s.l., the wide FOV telescopes will be re-arranged to measure shower fluorescence light and monitoring the space above the ground array from a distance of 4∼5km.
body_text.section: Extension to UHE for the second "knee"

body_text.text: The detector configuration is shown in Fig.4, in which the main detector array is composed of 16 telescopes covering elevations from 3 • to 59 • and two other detector arrays, covering elevations from 3 • to 31 • , to observe showers from perpendicular directions.
body_text.section: Extension to UHE for the second "knee"

body_text.text: Showers above 100PeV will be detected stereoscopically to maintain a high resolution of X max .
body_text.section: Extension to UHE for the second "knee"

body_text.text: Combining with the muon content measured by KM2A, the telescopes will achieve the spectrum and the composition measurements around the second knee.
body_text.section: Extension to UHE for the second "knee"

body_text.text: Conclusion
The ARGO-YBJ experiment has demonstrated a big potential in whole sky survey observation for both source population accumulation and transient phenomenon monitoring with an operation for 2∼3 years.
body_text.section: Conclusion

body_text.text: The LHAASO project is designed for greatly boost the capability, thus gamma ray sources will be surveyed above a few hundreds GeV.
body_text.section: Conclusion

body_text.text: Complementary with the CTA project, the focus of LHAASO experiment is mainly on full-sky survey and galactic cosmic ray origin search above 30TeV.
body_text.section: Conclusion

body_text.text: With an extension of using Cherenkov telescopes designed by the Magic group, a detailed source morphologic investigation is also in the extended scope of the project.
body_text.section: Conclusion

body_text.text: To maximize the advantage of being at high altitude, cosmic ray spectrum and composition will be measured over a wide energy range spanning a bridge between the balloon borne measurements for each species and UHECR observations above 1EeV at lower altitudes.
body_text.section: Conclusion
